Introduction

A varicocele is a common condition characterized by abnormal dilation of veins within the scrotum.  It typically presents in adolescents and young adults as a soft, irregular mass directly above the testis that may feel like a "bag of worms."  The mass typically increases in size with standing or Valsalva maneuver and decreases with recumbency.  Patients are often asymptomatic, but some experience a dull scrotal ache after prolonged standing or exertion.



The diagnosis is usually made clinically but can be confirmed with scrotal ultrasonography.  Most cases are managed with reassurance and observation.  However, a varicocele can impair fertility, and surgical repair may be necessary to preserve reproductive function.

Pathophysiology



A varicocele results from dilation of the pampiniform plexus, a network of veins that drain blood from the testicles.  It occurs more commonly on the left side due to anatomical differences in the left and right spermatic (gonadal) veins (

figure 1
).  The left spermatic vein is longer, originates at an angle perpendicular to the left renal vein, and is often compressed between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery.  This configuration increases intravascular pressure within the left gonadal vein, causing valve incompetence, retrograde blood flow, and venous dilation (especially worse when standing).  When the patient is supine, much of the blood returns to the systemic circulation, the plexus is decompressed, and the varicocele diminishes in size.



In contrast, the right spermatic vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava (IVC), so right-sided varicoceles are relatively rare.  A unilateral right varicocele or one that does not decrease in the recumbent position raises concern for a secondary cause of scrotal venous dilation, such as malignant compression by a renal or retroperitoneal mass (eg, Wilms tumor, renal cell carcinoma) or IVC thrombosis (

Risk factors



No specific risk factors exist for varicocele development, but the condition most often occurs in young, postpubertal males.  Rapid testicular growth during puberty is associated with increased blood flow to the testicles, which may explain the higher incidence of varicocele development at this age.

Pathology



Microscopically, a varicocele is characterized by venous distension, thickening of the vein walls, and loss of vascular elasticity.  Over time, this condition can lead to testicular hypoperfusion, hypoxia, and testicular atrophy (and infertility) if left untreated.

Clinical presentation



A varicocele most often presents with the following clinical features:



  • Asymptomatic (common) or dull, aching scrotal pain (which may worsen after physical exertion)
  • Tortuous enlargement of veins superior to the testis, often described as a "bag of worms"
  • Scrotal mass enlarges after standing and diminishes when supine
  • Mass does not transmit light shined through the scrotum (no transillumination)
  • Infertility, a common cause of reduced sperm production and impaired motility, presumably due to increased blood stasis and higher scrotal temperatures
  • Testicular atrophy

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of a varicocele is made clinically based on examination that reveals a soft, irregular mass in the left scrotum that does not transilluminate and improves in the supine position.  A scrotal ultrasonogram may be helpful if uncertainty exists.



However, a varicocele found in a prepubertal male (uncommon), that fails to decrease in size when supine, arises suddenly, or located on the right side is concerning for a secondary cause (eg, mass) and mandates further workup with abdominal ultrasonography or CT scan of the abdomen.

Differential diagnosis



  • Testicular tumors:  benign and malignant testicular tumors can present as a painless scrotal mass, but tumors are often firm or nodular rather than soft and compressible.  Tumors do not change size with Valsalva maneuver or change in position.
  • Hydrocele:  a fluid collection within the tunica vaginalis that causes painless testicular enlargement and reduces with recumbency, but the fluid easily transilluminates on examination.
  • Spermatocele:  a fluid-filled cyst of the head of the epididymis that presents as a painless mass at the superior pole of the testis.  It transilluminates and does not change size with positioning or Valsalva maneuver.
  • Inguinal hernia:  intraabdominal contents protrude through a weakened area in the inguinal canal, producing a painless, soft scrotal mass that increases with Valsalva maneuver and does not transilluminate.  However, hernias are often reducible with manipulation and do not have the characteristic "bag of worms" texture on palpation.
  • Epididymitis/orchitis:  unlike a varicocele, epididymitis and orchitis typically cause pain with localized tenderness and warmth on examination due to inflammation and infection.

Laboratory evaluation



Semen analysis to assess sperm count, motility, and morphology should be performed every 1-2 years in postpubertal patients with a varicocele and a desire to maintain fertility.  Any observed decline in fertility parameters warrants surgical management of the varicocele to preserve reproductive function.

Imaging



Doppler ultrasonography is the imaging modality of choice for confirming the diagnosis of a varicocele.  Findings include dilation of the pampiniform plexus veins, retrograde venous flow, and tortuous, anechoic tubules adjacent to the testis.

Management



Management strategies for a varicocele depend on the severity of symptoms and associated complications.



  • For most patients with a primary varicocele, management is with observation and reassurance.  An asymptomatic varicocele does not require treatment, especially in adolescents, as it may resolve spontaneously.  However, patient follow-up is necessary for signs of testicular atrophy or changes in semen analysis because this often warrants intervention.
  • For patients with minor pain, symptom management includes scrotal support garments, analgesics (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), and avoidance of prolonged standing/heavy lifting to minimize discomfort.
  • Surgical intervention (ligating or occluding gonadal vein branches to redirect blood and limit backflow into the venous plexus) is indicated if pain persists despite conservative measures.  Intervention is also recommended with testicular hypotrophy/atrophy and abnormal semen analysis in patients with a desire to maintain fertility (older patients without fertility concerns do not require surgical intervention).
  • If clinical findings suggest a secondary cause of a varicocele (eg, right-sided, prepubescent male), a CT scan of the abdomen or abdominal ultrasonogram is indicated to evaluate for a retroperitoneal/pelvic mass or IVC thrombus.

Prognosis



The prognosis for a varicocele is generally good, and conservative management is often adequate.  However, a varicocele can result in testicular atrophy, reduced sperm production, and impaired spermatic motility.  Patients with a varicocele who desire to maintain fertility should be monitored closely for any decline in sperm number or function.

Summary



A varicocele (
